sentences.sentence: “He is rich, that is certainly true, and you will have more fine clothes and fine carriages than Jane.
But will they make you happy?”
“Do you have any other objection,” said Elizabeth, “than that you believe I do not love him?”
“None at all.
We all know he is a proud, unpleasant sort of man.
But this would not matter if you really liked him.”
“I do, I do like him,” she replied, with tears in her eyes, “I love him. In fact, he is not overly( 太 ) proud.
He is perfectly friendly.
You do not know what he really is.
Please, do not upset me by speaking of him in such a way.”
“Lizzy,” said her father, “I have given him my consent( 同意 ).
He is the kind of man to whom I would never dare to refuse anything.
I now give it to you as well, if you are certain you want him.
But let me advise you to think about it some more.
I know your disposition( 性情 ), Lizzy.
I know that you can never be happy unless you truly respect and look up to your husband.
Your intelligence will cause many problems if you marry a man who is not worthy of you.
My child, do not make me suffer by seeing you unable to respect your partner in life.
You do not know what you are doing.”
Elizabeth, despite feeling great emotion( 激动 ), was serious and sincere( 真诚的 ) in her reply.
She repeatedly assured( 使放心 ) her father that Mr. Darcy was really the man she wanted, and explained how her opinion of him had gradually( 渐渐地 ) changed.
She expressed with energy all of his good qualities, and at last, she convinced( 说服 ) her father to accept the marriage.
In the hopes that she could improve her father’s impression of her future husband, she then told him what Mr. Darcy had chosen himself to do for Lydia.
He heard her with astonishment( 惊讶 ).
“So, Darcy did everything—arranged the marriage, gave the money, paid Wickham’s debts, and got him a new place in the army!
So much the better—it will save me a lot of trouble and money.
Had it been your uncle’s doing, I would have felt that I had to pay him back, but it is different with these hot-blooded young lovers.
I shall offer to pay him to-morrow, he will make a passionate( 热情的 ) speech about his love for you, and that will be the end of it.”
He then remembered noticing her embarrassment( 尴尬 ) a few days before, when Mr. Darcy had arrived unexpectedly.
And after laughing at( 嘲笑 ) her for some time, Mr. Bennet allowed her at last to go—saying, as she left the room,
“If any young men come for Mary or Kitty, send them in, for I am completely available.”
Elizabeth’s now felt very relieved that this difficult conversation was over.
After taking half an hour to think, quietly and alone in her own room, she was then able to rejoin( 再次加入 ) the others while still remaining calm.
The evening passed peacefully, because there was no longer anything to truly worry about.
With time, she knew that she would gradually( 渐渐地 ) feel more comfortable and at ease.
When her mother went up to her dressing-room that night, Elizabeth followed her, and told her the important news.
It had a very extraordinary effect on her mother.
When she first heard it, Mrs. Bennet sat very still, and was unable to say even a single word.
Many, many minutes passed before she could understand what she had heard.
She began at last to recover.
She moved around in her chair, got up, sat down again, wondered, and blessed herself.
“Good gracious( 天呐 )! Lord bless me! Dear me! Mr. Darcy! Who would have thought it!
And is it really true? Oh! My sweetest Lizzy! How rich and how great you will be! What money, what jewels( 珠宝 ), what carriages you will have!
Jane’s marriage cannot compare—no, not at all! I am so pleased—so happy.
Such a charming( 迷人的 ) man!—So handsome! So tall—Oh, my dear Lizzy! Please, apologize for me that I disliked him so much before.
I hope he will forget it.
Dear, dear Lizzy.
A house in town! Everything that is lovely! Three daughters married! Ten thousand a year!”
It was a happy day when Mrs. Bennet got rid of( 摆脱 ) her two most deserving daughters.
I wish I could say, for the sake( 原因 ) of her family, that her success made her a more sensible( 通情达理的 ), likable( 可爱的 ), intelligent woman for the rest of her life.
Perhaps, though, it was lucky for her husband that it did not, because he might not have enjoyed domestic( 家庭的 ) bliss( 福气 ) in so unusual a form.
Mr. Bennet missed his second daughter exceedingly( 极其地 ).
His affection( 喜爱 ) for her caused him to leave home more than he did for anything else.
He loved going to Pemberley, especially when he was least expected.
Mr. Bingley and Jane remained at Netherfield for only a year.
Even Mr. Bingley’s easy disposition( 性情 ), or Jane’s affectionate( 充满爱的 ) heart, could not stand living quite so near to her mother.
He bought a home not very far away from Pemberley, and Jane and Elizabeth were within thirty miles of each other.
As for Wickham and Lydia, their characters did not change greatly after they heard of the marriage of her sisters.
Lydia’s congratulatory letter to Elizabeth on her marriage, proved to her it was not likely that either were ever likely to change.
The letter was as follows:
MY DEAR LIZZY,
I wish you joy.
If you love Mr. Darcy half as well as I do my dear Wickham, you must be very happy.
It is a great comfort that you are so rich, and when you have nothing else to do, I hope you will think of us.
I am sure Wickham would like some more help with his career( 职业 ) very much, and I do not think we will have enough money to live on without some help.
Any help would do, that could provide an income of about three or four hundred pounds a year.
However, do not mention to Mr. Darcy that I asked, if you would prefer not to.
YOURS, LYDIA.
In fact, Elizabeth did prefer not to mention it to Mr. Darcy, and so she tried reply in a way that would remove any expectation of any further assistance( 帮助 ).
Still, she tried to send them something from her own personal spending money,
because she knew that such little income as theirs would never be enough to support their reckless( 鲁莽的 ) spending.
Though Darcy could never accept Wickham at Pemberley, Lydia was occasionally a visitor there, when her husband went to enjoy himself in London or Bath.
Eventually, Darcy helped Wickham further his career( 职业 ), although only for the sake( 原因 ) of Elizabeth.
Pemberley was now Miss Darcy’s home, and the sisters soon formed a close relationship, which was exactly what Darcy had hoped to see.
Georgiana had the highest opinion in the world of Elizabeth, although at first she often only listened with astonishment( 惊讶 ) at Elizabeth’s direct way of talking to her brother.
Eventually Elizabeth was able to explain to her that a wife may say things to her husband which a brother will not always allow.

Lady Catherine was extremely angry about the marriage of her nephew, and wrote to tell him so in language so abusive( 辱骂的 ), especially of Elizabeth, that for a while they had to cut off all connection with her.
But at last Elizabeth persuaded Darcy to forgive her and seek a reconciliation( 和解 ), and Lady Catherine finally condescended( 屈尊 ) to visit them at Pemberley
in spite of( 不管 ) the pollution which its noble heritage( 家世 ) had received from the presence of Elizabeth and the visits of her uncle and aunt.
With the Gardiners, they always kept up a very close relationship.
Darcy, as well as Elizabeth, really loved them.
They both always remembered that they owed( 欠 ) the warmest gratitude( 感激 ) toward the persons who, by bringing her to Pemberley, had brought the two of them together at last.

article_info.previous:
关于自己和Darcy的订婚，Elizabeth最担心的就是家人们的反应，因为他们不知道事情的真相，所以还是很不喜欢Mr.
 Darcy，Elizabeth最终抑制不住，告诉了Jane自己和Darcy的婚约，Jane十分惊讶。之后Darcy和Elizabeth决定前后分别去找Mr. Bennet和Mrs. Bennet商量他们的婚事，Mr. Bennet感到非常不安。
article_info.share_words: They both always remembered that they owed the warmest gratitude toward the person who, by bringing her to Pemberley, had brought the two of them together at last.

question.cn: Mr. Bennet第一次见Darcy时觉得他是怎样的人？
question.en: How did Mr. Bennet feel about Mr. Darcy when they first met?

options.cn: 他觉得Mr. Darcy很傲慢又讨厌。
options.en: He thought Mr. Darcy was proud and unpleasant.

options.cn: 他觉得Mr. Darcy既大方又友善。
options.en: He thought Mr. Darcy was generous and friendly.

options.cn: 他觉得Mr. Darcy既有钱又易相处。
options.en: He thought Mr. Darcy was rich and easy-going.

analysis: 文中Mr. Bennet说到：“None at all. We all know he is a proud, unpleasant sort of man. But this would not matter if you really liked him.” 所以选A。

question.cn: Mrs. Bennet对于Elizabeth的婚姻是什么感受？
question.en: How did Mrs. Bennet feel about Elizabeth's marriage?

analysis: 文中Mrs. Bennet说到：“‘Good gracious! Lord bless me! Dear me! Mr. Darcy!......I am so pleased—so happy. Such a charming man!—So handsome! So tall—Oh, my dear Lizzy!” 所以选B。

question.cn: Lydia在写给Elizabeth的信中说她想要什么帮助？
question.en: What help did Lydia  want in her letter to Elizabeth?

analysis: 文中信里提到：“I am sure Wickham would like some more help with his career very much, and I do not think we will have enough money to live on without some help.” 所以选C。

question.cn: Mr. Bennet一共有多少个女儿？
question.en: How many daughters did Mr. Bennet have?

analysis: 通读全文可知，Mr. Bennet有5个女儿，分别是Jane, Elizabeth, Lydia, Mary, Kitty.可知正确答案为C。

question.cn: Mr. Bingley从谁那里继承了近十万英镑？
question.en: From whom did Mr. Bingley inherit nearly a hundred thousand pounds?

analysis: 文中对话中提到：“Mr. Bingley had inherited property worth nearly a hundred thousand pounds from his father,” 所以选C。

question.cn: Mr. Bingley和Mr. Darcy是什么关系？
question.en: What was the relationship between Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy?

analysis: 文中提到：“Between Bingley and Darcy there was a very steady friendship, in spite of their very different characters.” 所以选B。

question.cn: Mr. Darcy为什么不和陌生人说话？
question.en: Why couldn't Mr. Darcy bring himself to talk to strangers?

options.cn: 因为他不想给自己找麻烦。
options.en: Because he didn’t want the trouble.

options.cn: 因为他害怕跟陌生人说话。
options.en: Because he was afraid to talk to them.

analysis: 文中提到：“‘I can answer your question,’ said Fitzwilliam, ‘without consulting him. It is because he will not give himself the trouble.’” 所以选B。

question.cn: 最开始时Elizabeth为什么不喜欢Mr. Darcy?
question.en: Why did Elizabeth dislike Mr. Darcy so much at first?

options.cn: 因为他插手了Jane的幸福并且残酷的对待Wickham。
options.en: Because he interfered with Jane's happiness and was cruel to Mr. Wickham.

analysis: 通读全文可知，Mr. Darcy最开始时很傲慢，不喜与人交谈，使得Elizabeth很不喜欢他，所以选择B。

question.cn: 从Catherine夫人那里可以得知，在很久以前Mr. Darcy就和谁订婚了？
question.en: According to Lady Catherine, who was Mr. Darcy engaged to before?

analysis: 文中提到：“This marriage, which you have been so reckless in encouraging, can never take place. No, never. Mr. Darcy is engaged to my daughter.”可知选择A。

question.cn: Mr. Darcy的父亲怎么看待Mr. Wickham？
question.en: What did Mr. Darcy's father think about Mr. Wickham?

options.en: He thought ill of Mr. Wickham.
He was fond of Mr. Wickham.
They did not know each other.

analysis: 文中信里提到：“My excellent father died about five years ago, and he remained very fond of Mr. Wickham right until the very end.” 所以选B。

question.cn: 为什么Mr. Wickham让自己去吸引Georgiana？
question.en: Why would Mr. Wickham make himself attractive to Georgiana?

options.cn: 因为他全心全意地爱着她。
options.en: Because he loved her with all his heart.
Because he was asked to do so.
Because he was after her wealth.

analysis: 文中信里提到：“Mr. Wickham's main goal was undoubtedly my sister's wealth, for she will have thirty thousand pounds once she marries or turns twenty-one.” 所以选C

question.cn: 管家对Mr. Darcy是什么看法？
question.en: What opinion did the housekeeper have of Mr. Darcy?

analysis: 文中housekeeper说到：“He is always very kind to his servants, to his tenants, and to the poor......who think of nothing but themselves.” 所以选A。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第100天
